section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background, engage children with thematic music, and introduce vocabulary (vase, stared).
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking, How does Marisol feel about Ramon’s art?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening; Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Take initiative.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work.
Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Discuss and describe the content of real paintings.
Ask children to select one favorite painting to “hang on their wall.”
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you name a book that has great illustrations? What is it called?
Pretend to be Ramon. How does he act?
Can you use number cubes to make art? How many did you use?
Write or draw the names of two things you like to draw.
Make something that Ramon drew in the book.
Find the letters that spell A-R-T.
Use blocks to make a place where Ramon could show off his drawings.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Mind Builders: Emotional Development; Social Development

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder show pride and introduce vocabulary (burst out, family).
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Ish.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Make connections between situations.
Show interest and appreciation for others’ work; Use art for self-expression.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children describe pride as shown by people in photographs.
Guide children to make up and tell a story about the event pictured.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Find a picture of someone who looks proud.
Show how you look and move when you are proud of something you have done.
The lion is sometimes called the king of the beasts. Can you draw a picture of a proud lion?
Write or draw about one thing that makes you proud.
Color or paint yourself wearing an outfit that makes you proud.
Find the letter that starts the word proud. Name some other words that start the same way.
Build a house from your imagination.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ish by Peter H. Reynolds. Copyright © 2004 by Peter H. Reynolds. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust. Photo © Stephen Rees/Shutterstock.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill Speak Clearly and introduce vocabulary (loose, worry).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Ish and asking the guiding question, What lesson does Ramon learn about making art?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Sustain attention while listening.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Identify rhyming words.
Show interest in and appreciation for others’ work.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Ask children to listen to and follow oral directions.
Guide children to create loose and flowing drawings.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find a book that has illustrations you love? What do you love about them?
Show how you can dance or move in a loose, silly way.
Show a pile of 3 counters and a pile of 5 counters. Could a pile have 5-ish counters? Can some things be loose while others must be exact?
Write or draw how you feel when you have no worries at all.
Use any tools you like. Make art that is loose and worry-free.
Find the letters i-s-h. Can you find a letter to go before those letters and make a word?
Build a tower. Can you make your tower very strong? Can you make your tower loose? Can a tower be loose but not fall down?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ish by Peter H. Reynolds. Copyright © 2004 by Peter H. Reynolds. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Photos © Shutterstock: crayons (Lucie Lang), paper (jannoon028), pencils (urfin).

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Big Chart of Big Ideas: A Horse, of Course

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about what children have learned about making art and introduce vocabulary words (sculpt, mold).
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts A Horse, of Course and Ish .
Read closely to connect to the big question, How can we express ourselves through making art?
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Sustain attention while listening; Respond appropriately to spoken language.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Express pride in age-appropriate skills
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Use art for self-expression; Show interest in and appreciation for others’ work.
Experiment with a variety of fine-motor tasks but may lack strength and control.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children differentiate among verbs that tell about making art.
Ask children to draw cards and pair up to find the matching verbs.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Compare two books. How did the illustrators make the pictures? Which do you like better and why?
Decide whether you want to sculpt or paint. Act it out.
Name one animal you would like to draw. Name one colorful animal you would like to paint. Why did you choose those animals?
Write about horses. Why do you think artists like to draw, paint, and sculpt them?
Use your art skills to make your favorite animal.
What letter does the name of your favorite animal start with? Can you write it?
Use blocks to make a place for horses to live.

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Ish by Peter H. Reynolds. Copyright © 2004 by Peter H. Reynolds. Published by Scholastic Inc. by arrangement with Candlewick Press.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to have children show and tell about their own art, sing a color song, and introduce vocabulary (crumpled, gallery).
Begin Story Time by revisiting Ish and asking the guiding question, Does art have to be perfect? Why or why not?
Read and retell interactively for deeper emotional connection to the text.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Speak clearly enough to be understood.
Use complete sentences of four or more words.
Express pride in age-appropriateskills
Show self-awareness in different/multiple ways.
Engage in conflict resolution.
Share and repeat the details in a text.
Write for different purposes.
Show interest in and appreciation for others’ work.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: What can you say to your friends to help them feel proud of their artwork?
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s work to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How can we express ourselves through making art?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote a book, what kind of illustrations would you draw?
Paint a picture to give to a friend or family member.
Draw and decorate your favorite shape. What shape did you choose?
Find one piece of art you made. Write a name for it.
Make a piece of art that shows how you feel. What colors will it have? How big will it be?
Create an alphabet book page. Choose your favorite letter and make an illustration to match it.
Build a design with blocks. Then share with a friend. Ask what your friend likes most about your design and say what you like most about theirs. Do you and your friend agree?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Increase listening vocabulary and begin to develop vocabulary of object names and common phrases.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Count 1–10 items with one count per item.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Make connections between situations.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Recognize rhyming words.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Sustain attention while listening; Show understanding by responding appropriately.
Use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Understand shades of meaning among verbs.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Use art as a form of creative self-expression and representation.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
Show control of tasks that require small-muscle strength and control.
Speech is understood by both the teacher and other adults in the school.
Use complete sentences of four or more words and grammatical complexity, usually with subject, verb, and object orders.
Show self-awareness and express pride in age-appropriate abilities and skills.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek help when necessary.
Retell or reenact a story after it is read aloud.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
Demonstrate interest in and show appreciation for the creative work of others.
